◆ opApplicationHeaderRead()

Bool opApplicationHeaderRead ( const char *  file,
ordObjectInfoP  info 
)

Read the header of an application file, trying each of the available application readers in turn until one is successful. All simulator products include an ELF format reader, other products include other format readers, such as COFF. Custom loaders can also be installed in the product.

Returns
True if read successfully.
Parameters
fileThe application program file to be read.
infoThe pointer to the info structure, filled in by this call. Refer to the ordObjectInfoP structure in ImpPublic/include/host/ord/ordTypes.h
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Construction
See also
opApplicationLoaderInstall

◆ opApplicationLoaderInstall()

Bool opApplicationLoaderInstall ( const char *  file)

Install a custom loader for application programs. Refer to the Custom Object Reader Guide.

Returns
True if installed successfully.
Parameters
fileThe filename of the custom loader shared object
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Construction
Restrictions:
The custom loader must be loaded before an application is loaded. Note that each loader type is tried in turn until one is successful. Custom loaders are tried before the standard loaders, so can replace them.
Examples:
  • SimulationControl/customApplicationLoader

◆ opBridgeNew()

optBridgeP opBridgeNew ( optModuleP  module,
const char *  name,
optConnectionsP  connections,
optParamP  params 
)

Add an instance of a bridge to a module. A bridge connects two buses. There must be one bus master connection and one bus slave. Use the OP_CONNECTIONS, OP_BUS_CONNECTIONS and OP_BUS_CONNECT macros. The bus slave connection connects to the bus that will initiate transactions, and specifies the range of addresses on the initiator that will pass over the bridge. The bus master connection connects to the target bus and specifies the address range generated on this bus. Note that the number of bytes on each bus must be the same. Note that a bridge does not affect the size or type of transaction.

Returns
The new bridge instance
Parameters
moduleThe parent module instance
nameThe name of the new instance. This string is copied so need not persist.
connectionsLists of connections. Refer to the optConnectionsP structure.
paramsA list of parameters to configure the new instance
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Construction
Examples:
  • Simple example

◆ opBridgeNext()

optBridgeP opBridgeNext ( optModuleP  module,
optBridgeP  bridge 
)

This function returns the next bridge from a module. To get the first object, bridge should be null.

Parameters
moduleThe parent object.
bridgeThe iterator. Pass null to get the first object.
Returns
Returns the next bridge, or null when there are no more objects.
Example:
optBridgeP obj = 0;
while((obj = opBridgeNext(parent, obj))) {
opPrintf("found bridge called '%s'\n", opObjectName(obj));
}
Examples:
  • PlatformConstruction/walker

◆ opBusAccessWatchpointNew()

optWatchpointP opBusAccessWatchpointNew ( optBusP  bus,
Addr  addrLo,
Addr  addrHi,
void *  userData,
optAddrWatchpointConditionFn  notifierCB 
)

Set a watchpoint to occur on a bus access. When a watchpoint is triggered, if the notifierCB is specified, it will be called. If it returns True, simulation will continue, otherwise it will stop. If the function is not specified the simulator will stop. The simulator stops by returning to its caller immediately after the access has completed.

Returns
New watchpoint
Parameters
busThe bus instance
addrLoThe lower address limit
addrHiThe upper address limit
userDataPointer available in the watchpoint
notifierCBNotifier function
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Simulation
  • Pre-simulation
Examples:
  • Simple example

◆ opBusSlaveNew()

optBusSlaveP opBusSlaveNew ( optBusP  bus,
const char *  name,
optProcessorP  proc,
optPriv  privilege,
Addr  addrLo,
Addr  addrHi,
optBusSlaveReadFn  rcb,
optBusSlaveWriteFn  wcb,
void *  nativeMemory,
void *  userData 
)

Implement an address region as a combination of callbacks or native memory. Read and write operations to the range from addrLo to addrHi will cause the rcb and wcb functions to be called. Arguments rcb or wcb can be set to null, in which case the native memory will be used instead. In this case nativeMemory must be passed a pointer to host memory that was pre-allocated with sufficient size by the user. (When allocating very large memories, be careful not to exhaust the finite resources of your host computer). Additionally, the privilege argument can be used to prevent read or write access to the region. Refer to optPriv. Violation of the specified privilege causes a privilege exception in the initiating device. Use the OP_BUS_SLAVE_READ_FN and OP_BUS_SLAVE_WRITE_FN macros to define the callbacks. If name is supplied, the slave will be a permanent part of the platform; if null, the slave will be temporary and not checked for overlap with other devices on the bus.

Returns
Returns the new bus slave if successful.
Parameters
busThe bus instance
nameThe name of the slave address region
procOptional processor context. If valid, only this processor will trigger the callback.
privilegeThe read-write-execute access privilege
addrLoThe lower address limit
addrHiThe upper address limit
rcbThe function called to implement bus reads
wcbThe function called to implement bus writes
nativeMemoryPointer to native memory
userDataThe user data
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Construction
  • Pre-simulation
  • Simulation
Examples:
  • PlatformConstruction/usingExternalMemory
  • SimulationControl/dynamicBridge
  • PlatformConstruction/busHierarchy

◆ opCmdParserAdd()

void opCmdParserAdd ( optCmdParserP  parser,
const char *  name,
const char *  shortName,
const char *  argDesc,
const char *  group,
optFlagType  type,
void *  pointer,
const char *  description,
optArgClass  useMask,
Uns32  userData,
Bool  mandatory 
)

Add an option to the parser. The parser will then be able to parse the option and its following argument and take the action specified. Actions are to either update a variable of the correct type, pointed to by the pointer argument, or to call a function of correct type, pointed to by the pointer argument.

Parameters
parserThe parser instance
nameThe new flag name
shortNameOptional single character alternative name
argDescOptional description of the value that must follow this argument
groupOptional group. All options with the same group will appear together when -help is specified.
typeArgument type (see the FlagType enumerated type)
pointerPointer to either a callback function, or to the data item to be modified
descriptionThis is printed when -help is specified
useMaskA bit-mask to control if this flag is visible under -help. The mask corresponds to the ArgClass passed to opCmdParserNew.
userDataThe user data to be passed to a callback function
mandatoryIf true, this argument must be specified
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Construction
Restrictions:
Adding an argument name or a short name that already exists will cause a fatal error. The argument type and the type of object pointed to by the pointer argument must agree, otherwise the program will produce a segmentation violation.
Examples:
  • SimulationControl/moduleSaveRestore
  • SimulationControl/loadingApplicationPrograms
  • SimulationControl/recordReplay
  • SimulationControl/startingApplicationDebug
  • PlatformConstruction/walker
See also
opCmdParserNew opCmdParserReplace

◆ opCmdParserDelete()

argDescOptional description of the value that must follow this argument
groupOptional group. All options with the same group will appear together when -help is specified.
typeArgument type (see the FlagType enumerated type)
pointerPointer to either a callback function, or to the data item to be modified
descriptionThis is printed when -help is specified
useMaskA bit-mask to control if this flag is visible under -help. The mask corresponds to the ArgClass passed to opCmdParserNew.
userDataThe user data to be passed to a callback function
mandatoryIf true, this argument must be specified
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Construction
Restrictions:
Replacing a vital argument will make the product unusable. The argument type and the type of object pointed to by the pointer argument must agree, otherwise the program will produce a segmentation violation.
See also
opCmdParserAdd

◆ opDocSectionAdd()

optDocNodeP opDocSectionAdd ( optDocNodeP  parent,
const char *  name 
)

Create a documentation node representing a section heading. A module can create its own documentation using opDocSectionAdd and opDocTextAdd, so that it can be used in other designs without publishing its source. Use opDocSectionAdd to create a root node, then use opDocSectionAdd to create a section heading and opDocTextAdd to create paragraphs following the heading. Use opDocSectionAdd to create sub-section headings.

Returns
The new documentation node
Parameters
parentThe parent node
nameThe section name
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Construction
Examples:
  • Simple example

◆ opInterrupt()

void opInterrupt ( void  )

This and opInterruptRSP are the only OP functions that are safe to call in a signal handler. This function causes any currently-executing simulation thread to stop as soon as possible in a safe state so that other ICM functions can be called. The stop is signalled by a return code stop reason of OP_SR_INTERRUPT. The thread stops just before the next code block is executed; typically, this will be a few instructions on from the icmInterrupt call. It is safe to use opInterrupt in non-signal-handler contexts (e.g. memory callbacks) but you may want to consider the use of opProcessorYield in this context.

Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Pre-simulation
  • Simulation
  • Post-simulation
Restrictions:
Do not call this function from another host thread unless the simulator thread has been stopped.
Examples:
  • SimulationControl/interruptSimulation
  • SimulationControl/interruptSimulation

◆ opInterruptRSP()

void opInterruptRSP ( void  )

This and opInterrupt are the only OP functions that are safe to call in a signal handler. This function causes simulation to stop and return control to a debugger connected through RSP. If no debugger is attached, simulation continues.

Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Pre-simulation
  • Simulation
  • Post-simulation
Restrictions:
Do not call this function from another host thread unless the simulator thread has been stopped.

◆ opMMCNew()

optMMCP opMMCNew ( optModuleP  module,
const char *  path,
const char *  name,
optConnectionsP  connections,
optParamP  params 
)

Load an MMC shared object and create an MMC instance. An MMC model can model a cache or similar bus-oriented device. Refer to the OVP VMI Memory Model Component Function Reference. An MMC must be connected to two or more buses. An MMC is a target on the bus connected to its slave port and is an initiator on the bus connected to its master port.

Returns
The new MMC instance
Parameters
moduleThe parent module instance
pathPath to MMC model (refer to opVLNVString())
nameThe name of the new instance. This string is copied so need not persist.
connectionsLists of connections. Refer to the optConnectionsP structure.
paramsA list of parameters to configure the new instance
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Construction
Examples:
  • Simple example

)

◆ opMemoryAccessWatchpointNew()

optWatchpointP opMemoryAccessWatchpointNew ( optMemoryP  memory,
Addr  addrLo,
Addr  addrHi,
void *  userData,
optAddrWatchpointConditionFn  notifierCB 
)

Set a watchpoint to occur on a memory access. When a watchpoint is triggered, if the notifierCB is specified, it will be called. If it returns True, simulation will continue, otherwise it will stop. If the function is not specified the simulator will stop. The simulator stops by returning to its caller immediately after the access has completed.

Returns
New watchpoint
Parameters
memoryThe memory
addrLoThe lower address limit
addrHiThe upper address limit
userDataPointer available in the watchpoint
notifierCBNotifier function
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Simulation
  • Pre-simulation
Examples:
  • Simple example

◆ opMemorySpecParse()

Uns32 opMemorySpecParse ( const char *  spec,
optMemorySpecP  specArray,
Uns32  max 
)

Parse a memory specification in the form [name:]addrLo:addrHi[:priv[:shared]][,repeat]. Privilege must be a combination of r,w,x and - (case insensitive). Memories without a name will be called mem0, mem1 etc. Memories without privilege will be rwx.

Returns
The number of parsed memory specifications
Parameters
specThe memory specification string
specArrayArray of memory specifications to be filled
maxNumber of entries in the array (will not be exceeded)
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Construction
Notes:
If the names are not specified, names mem0, mem1 etc are created, without regard for any other names in existence. Care should be taken to avoid clashes with other objects in the same scope.
See also
opMemoryNew

◆ opMemoryWriteWatchpointNew()

optWatchpointP opMemoryWriteWatchpointNew ( optMemoryP  memory,
Addr  addrLo,
Addr  addrHi,
void *  userData,
optAddrWatchpointConditionFn  notifierCB 
)

Set a watchpoint on a memory write write. When a watchpoint is triggered, if the notifierCB is specified, it will be called. If it returns True, simulation will continue, otherwise it will stop. If the function is not specified the simulator will stop. The simulator stops by returning to its caller immediately after the access has completed.

Returns
New watchpoint
Parameters
memoryThe memory
addrLoThe lower address limit
addrHiThe upper address limit
userDataPointer available in the watchpoint
notifierCBNotifier function
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Simulation
  • Pre-simulation
Examples:
  • SimulationControl/addingWatchpoints

◆ opMessage()

void opMessage ( const char *  severity,
const char *  ident,
const char *  fmt,
  ... 
)

Send formatted text to the simulator output stream. The text is prefixed with the severity and a prefix code which should be a short string. Use this for user-level diagnostics.

Parameters
severityI=Info, W=Warning, E=Error, F=Fatal (aborts the simulator)
identA short, easily searched code to identify this message
fmtPrintf format string (see gnu printf for details)
...This is a vararg function
Phase:
Can be used in any phase
Notes:
If the message does not end with a newline, opMessage inserts a newline at the end of the text
Examples:
  • SimulationControl/processorModelSaveRestoreValidation
  • SimulationControl/loadingApplicationPrograms
  • SimulationControl/interruptSimulation
  • SimulationControl/startingApplicationDebug
  • PlatformConstruction/walker

◆ opModuleNew()

optModuleP opModuleNew ( optModuleP  module,
const char *  path,
const char *  name,
optConnectionsP  connections,
optParamP  params 
)

Add an instance of a module to another module by loading a module file. This function does the following steps, with error detection at each stage. - Locate and load the passed shared object (DLL) - Find the symbol 'modelAttrs' to locate the entry point structure. - Check that the shared object is the right type - a module. - Check the version field against this simulator. - Allocate space for the module's persistent data if required. - Call the iterator functions to verify the parameters, bus, net, FIFO and packetnet connections against those expected. - Call the constructor. Note that this will cause the construction of sub-modules and other model instances.

Returns
The new module instance
Parameters
moduleThe parent module instance
pathPath to the module, usually calculated by opVLNVString()
nameThe name of the new instance or null. This string is copied so need not persist. If null the name is taken from the model (but only one instance like this will be allowed)
connectionsLists of connections. Refer to the optConnectionsP structure.
paramsA list of parameters to configure the new instance
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Construction
Notes:
The object file will be loaded the first time it is referenced by this function. Subsequent references will re-use the object. Thus any data declared 'static' in the module, will be shared by all instances.
Examples:
  • SimulationControl/moduleSaveRestore
  • SimulationControl/processorModelSaveRestoreValidation
  • SimulationControl/loadingApplicationPrograms
  • SimulationControl/recordReplay
  • PlatformConstruction/staticBridgeHierarchy
See also
opVLNVString opRootModuleNew

◆ opModuleNewFromAttrs()

optModuleP opModuleNewFromAttrs ( optModuleP  module,
optModuleAttrP  attrs,
const char *  name,
optConnectionsP  connections,
optParamP  params 
)

Add an instance of a module to another module using a module modelAttrs structure. This is similar to opModuleNew, but uses a modelAttrs structure (and the functions it refers to) from code that is already loaded - probably part of this file.

Returns
The new module instance
Parameters
moduleThe parent module instance
attrsThe attributes table
nameThe name of the new instance or null. The string is copied so need not persist. If null the name is taken from the model (but only one instance like this will be allowed)
connectionsLists of connections. Refer to the optConnectionsP structure.
paramsA list of parameters to configure the new instance
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Construction

◆ opModuleNext()

optModuleP opModuleNext ( optModuleP  parent,
optModuleP  module 
)

This function returns the next module from a parent. To get the first object, module should be null. If parent is null, this function returns the next root module.

Parameters
parentThe parent object.
moduleThe iterator. Pass null to get the first object.
Returns
Returns the next module, or null when there are no more objects.
Example:
optModuleP obj = 0;
while((obj = opModuleNext(parent, obj))) {
opPrintf("found module called '%s'\n", opObjectName(obj));
}

◆ opObjectByName()

optObjectP opObjectByName ( optObjectP  object,
const char *  name,
optStrType  mask 
)

Find any object by its hierarchical name. The hierarchy delimiter is '/'. Wildcards '*' and '?' are allowed between delimiters. If a wildcard matches multiple objects, the first will be returned.

Returns
Platform object of any type
Parameters
objectThe root of the search
nameThe hierarchical name (names separated by the '/' character).

optCommandP  current 
)

This function returns the next current from a object. To get the first object, current should be null.

Parameters
objectThe parent object.
currentThe iterator. Pass null to get the first object.
Returns
Returns the next current, or null when there are no more objects.
Example:
optCommandP obj = 0;
while((obj = opObjectCommandNext(parent, obj))) {
opPrintf("found current called '%s'\n", opObjectName(obj));
}

◆ opPacketnetMonitorNext()

optPacketnetMonitorP opPacketnetMonitorNext ( optPacketnetP  packetnet,
optPacketnetMonitorP  packetnetMonitor 
)

This function returns the next packetnetMonitor from a packetnet. To get the first object, packetnetMonitor should be null.

Parameters
packetnetThe parent object.
packetnetMonitorThe iterator. Pass null to get the first object.
Returns
Returns the next packetnetMonitor, or null when there are no more objects.
Example:
optPacketnetMonitorP obj = 0;
while((obj = opPacketnetMonitorNext(parent, obj))) {
opPrintf("found packetnetMonitor called '%s'\n", opObjectName(obj));
}
Examples:
  • PlatformConstruction/walker

◆ opPacketnetNew()

optPacketnetP opPacketnetNew ( optModuleP  module,
const char *  name,
const char *  portName,
optParamP  params 
)

Add an instance of a packetnet to a module (with an optional external packetnet port)

Returns
The new packetnet instance
Parameters
moduleThe parent module instance
nameThe name of the new instance. This string is copied so need not persist.
portNameIf specified, this parameter creates a module packetnet port of this name so that other modules can connect to this packetnet.
paramsA list of parameters to configure the new instance
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Construction
Examples:
  • PlatformConstruction/packetnetHierarchy

◆ opProcessorAccessWatchpointNew()

Bool  physical,

Addr  addrHi,
void *  userData,
optAddrWatchpointConditionFn  notifierCB 
)

Set a watchpoint to trigger when processor performs a memory access in the given address range. When a watchpoint is triggered, if the notifierCB is specified, it will be called. If it returns True, simulation will continue, otherwise it will stop. If the function is not specified the simulator will stop. The simulator stops by returning to its caller immediately after the access has completed.

New watchpoint

◆ opProcessorDerate()

void opProcessorDerate ( optProcessorP  processor,
double  factor 
)

This function sets an external de-rate factor for a processor (0-100%, default 0%). This enables the simulation environment to indicate that the processor should execute at a reduced percentage of its configured MIPS rate. This is necessary for the platform to be able to simulate the effect of reduced-rate clocking, for example.

Parameters
processorProcessor object.
factorDe-rating factor

◆ opProcessorRegWatchpointNew()

optWatchpointP opProcessorRegWatchpointNew ( optProcessorP  processor,
optRegP  reg,
optRegWatchpointMode  mode,
void *  userData,
optProcWatchpointConditionFn  notifierCB 
)

Set a watchpoint on a processor register. The notifier function will be called when the register changes value. When a watchpoint is triggered, if the notifierCB is specified, it will be called. If it returns True, simulation will continue, otherwise it will stop. If the function is not specified the simulator will stop. The simulator stops by returning to its caller immediately after the instruction has completed.

Returns
New watchpoint
Parameters
processorProcessor containing the watched register
regThe register to be watched
modeMode: see optRegWatchpointMode
userDataThe user data passed to the callback

processorProcessor object.

◆ opProcessorStopReason()

optStopReason opProcessorStopReason ( optProcessorP  processor)

Return the reason why the given processor stopped after a previous simulation using opProcessorSimulate() or opRootModuleSimulate(). The stop reason is valid only for leaf level processors or an MT group: processor objects that are containers of independently-executable cores always return a stopReason of OP_SR_SCHED, because each of the sub-cores may have a different stopReason.

Returns
The reason why this processor stopped executing.
Parameters
processorThe processor instance
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Pre-simulation
  • Simulation
  • Post-simulation
Notes:
The simulator can stop execution of a particular processor because: - the processor cannot continue for a specific reason. - the processor has executed a quantum's worth of instructions and it's now the turn of another processor. The stop reason will be OP_SR_SCHED (This occurs even when there is only one processor in the design).
Examples:
  • SimulationControl/processorModelSaveRestoreValidation
  • SimulationControl/processorResetControl
  • SimulationControl/processorExternalInterruptControl
  • DebuggerIntegration/modeAndException
  • DebuggerIntegration/multiProcessor

◆ opProcessorUnfreeze()

void opProcessorUnfreeze ( optProcessorP  processor)

Following this function call, the given processor will be scheduled normally. If as a result of being in the frozen state, this processor has executed fewer instructions than other processors, it will be scheduled to run until it has caught up, thus minimizing any disturbance caused by the use of opProcessorFreeze.

◆ opProcessorWriteWatchpointNew()

optWatchpointP opProcessorWriteWatchpointNew ( optProcessorP  processor,
Bool  physical,
Addr  addrLo,
Addr  addrHi,
void *  userData,
optAddrWatchpointConditionFn  notifierCB 
)

Set a watchpoint to trigger when processor performs a memory write in the given address range. When a watchpoint is triggered, if the notifierCB is specified, it will be called. If it returns True, simulation will continue, otherwise it will stop. If the function is not specified the simulator will stop. The simulator stops by returning to its caller immediately after the access has completed.

Returns
New watchpoint
Parameters
processorThe processor instance
physicalUse physical addresses
addrLoThe lower address limit
addrHiThe upper address limit
userDataPointer available in the watchpoint
notifierCBNotifier function
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Simulation
  • Pre-simulation
Examples:
  • DebuggerIntegration/modeAndException
  • DebuggerIntegration/multiProcessor
  • SimulationControl/addingWatchpoints

◆ opResetErrors()

Uns32 opResetErrors ( Uns32  count)

OP messages with Error status add to the simulator's total error count. A non-zero error count prevents the simulator from moving from one phase to the next e.g. an error during construction prevents simulation. Using this function to reset the error count to zero will allow the simulator to continue. Use with care; the simulation might continue with a potentially fatal error.

Returns
The current error count prior to this call
Parameters
countThe required error count
Phase:
Can be used in any phase
See also
opErrors

◆ opRootModuleSetWallClockFactor()

double opRootModuleSetWallClockFactor ( optModuleP  module,
double  factor 
)

When running in wallclock mode (wallclock specified), this gives the maximum multiple of real time at which the simulation should run. The default is 1.0, implying no faster than real time. An value of 2.0 implies no faster than twice real time; a value of 0.5 implies no faster than half realtime

Returns
Returns the new factor, or zero if it could not be set
Parameters
moduleThe parent module instance
factorWallclock factor to apply.
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Construction
  • Pre-simulation
  • Simulation

◆ opRootModuleSimulate()

optProcessorP opRootModuleSimulate ( optModuleP  module)

Simulate a platform using the simulator's built-in scheduler.

Returns
The processor that was running when the simulation stopped
Parameters
moduleThe root module instance
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Construction
  • Pre-simulation
  • Simulation
Notes:
When called the first time, this function will call the post-elaborate callbacks, then the pre-simulate callbacks in all sub-modules. Every time it is called (until simulation is finished) it will call the simulate callbacks then begin processor simulation.
Restrictions:
Do not mix the use of opRootModuleSimulate (which uses the built-in simulator scheduler), with opProcessorSimulate (which assumes that the user is managing processor scheduling). If using this function, do not use opRootModuleTimeAdvance.
Examples:
  • SimulationControl/moduleSaveRestore
  • SimulationControl/processorModelSaveRestoreValidation
  • SimulationControl/loadingApplicationPrograms
  • SimulationControl/recordReplay
  • PlatformConstruction/staticBridgeHierarchy

◆ opSessionDebuggerNotifiersAdd()

void opSessionDebuggerNotifiersAdd ( optModuleP  root,
optDebuggerNotifiersP  notifiers 
)

Install callbacks for a debugger integration. The callbacks are passed in the notifiers structure. Each callback passes control to the debugger. The debugger code must then take appropriate action. In the callbacks, the simulator is stopped and stable. It is therefore safe to examine memory and processors, add or remove breakpoints, watchpoints etc. This function can be called before the root module is created - pass null to the root parameter.

Parameters
rootThe root module instance
notifiersCallback structure
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Construction
Restrictions:
Although the simulator can have more than one root module in a session, only one root module can be connected to a debugger. This function must be called after the root module is constructed but before its contents are added.
See also
optDebuggerNotifiers

◆ opSessionInit()

optSessionStatus opSessionInit ( const char *  version)

Start a session. Each session is started with opSessionInit() and finished with opSessionTerminate(). This sequence can be repeated. Finally call opSessionExit() to exit the process.

Returns
If the environment variable IMPERAS_SESSION_ERROR_RETURN=1 : Returns OP_SESSION_OK if successful or an error code if not. If IMPERAS_SESSION_ERROR_RETURN=0 or unset : Does not return; session will finish.
Parameters
versionAPI Version string (must be the macro OP_VERSION)
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Construction
Restrictions:
Each call of opSessionInit() should be matched with opSessionTerminate(). opSessionExit() should be called to exit the process.
Examples:
  • SimulationControl/moduleSaveRestore
  • SimulationControl/processorModelSaveRestoreValidation
  • SimulationControl/loadingApplicationPrograms
  • SimulationControl/recordReplay
  • PlatformConstruction/staticBridgeHierarchy
See also
opSessionTerminate opSessionExit

◆ opVLNVString()

const char* opVLNVString ( const char *  vlnvroot,
const char *  vendor,
const char *  library,
const char *  name,
const char *  version,
optModelType  type,
optVLNVError  reportErrors 
)

Synthesize a VLNV path string given the vendor, library, name and version of the library object you wish to load, and see if it exists. If models are stored according to Imperas guidelines, this should successfully locate any model. If all arguments are plain strings, constructs a path such as 'vlnvroot/vendor/library/name/version/objtype', otherwise the following rules are used: If vlnvroot is null, the default installation path is used. vlnvroot may be a list of paths separated by ':' (on Linux) or ';' (on Windows)

Returns
Null if no file is found, otherwise a file path
Parameters
vlnvrootPath or list of paths to root of directory(s) containing modelsT
vendorVendor directory e.g. yourcompany.com. This can be null or include glob characters
libraryLibrary directory e.g. processor. This can be null or include glob characters
nameThe name directory e.g. risc32. This can be null or include glob characters
versionVersion directory e.g. 1.0. This can be null or include glob characters
typeType of model to be found.
reportErrorsThe action when a single model cannot be found
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Construction
Examples:
  • SimulationControl/processorQuery
  • SimulationControl/moduleSaveRestore
  • PlatformConstruction/simpleCpuMemoryUartUsingOP
  • PlatformConstruction/simpleCpuMemoryUartUsingOPandHarnessExe
  • SimulationControl/dynamicHarness

watchpointThe watchpoint to be deleted
Phase:
Can be used in these phases:
  • Pre-simulation
  • Simulation
  • Post-simulation
Examples:
  • DebuggerIntegration/multiProcessor
